AI Tools for Academic Research and Writing

New tools are constantly emerging from LLMs (Large Language Models) that use generative AI to produce new analysis, text, or to answer questions.  Below I have listed some AI tools that are especially developed to aid with scholarly research.  Please note that listing these tools does not imply that I encourage or endorse them. I have listed the UConn Compliance rules with regards to AI in the next section of this page.  Please be aware of the risks and consequences of uploading information to AI tools with regards to either:

  • sensitive or confidential information (DO NOT under any circumstance upload sensitive, confidential, or proprietary information to these tools)
  • copyright infringement (many publishers/journals/authors prohibit the uploading of articles or their writing to LLMs)
  • data ownership policies (read the fine print)
  • AI hallucinations. An AI hallucination is incorrect or misleading information generated by an AI model. AI tools can hallucinate references, resources, and links. They can make up references that look legitimate, but are false or do not exist.  Do not blindly trust references given by chat prompt LLM AI tools like Chat GPT. You must verify the references given by a LLM against a legitimate library academic database citation.  

That being said, we now live in the era of ubiquitous AI. Many of these tools developed specifically for researchers can be very useful.  Best practices with regards to using AI include acknowledgement of the use of an AI tool in your work, citation, and checking for errors,

Make sure you A.C.E. your use of these tools by:

  • Acknowledging that you used a LLM AI tool in your research or assignment
  • Citing the tool in your bibliography or list of Works Cited
  • Evaluating for errors: check for errors in references; is the information given by the AI tool true? Does it add value?

This list was created by and is maintained by STEM librarian Renée Walsh. Renée created the acronym A.C.E. as a pedagogical mnemonic device. It can be reused and remixed by attribution under a CC-BY Open Commons license.

Remember to Acknowledge, Cite, and Evaluate! A.C.E.

Are you interested in professional development about generative AI from UConn?  Please see the link below to UConn CETL workshops as well as a link to the UConn BEACON AI club.

  • CETL Generative AI Workshops
  • BEACON: Beneficial and Ethical AI at UConn Club
    UConn club of folks interested in ethical AI. Hosts reading group and other events.
  • AI Hacks for Educators
    An OER book created by the University of Central Florida that is referenced in CETL AI trainings for faculty
  • Generative AI Google Doc Tracker from ITHAKA S&R
    Compares and contrasts AI tools

Before you begin to use an A.I. tool, it may be helpful to think about how and why you are using it. How are you critically using the actions below when engaging with generative A.I.?

  • Bloom's Taxonomy Revisited from Oregon State University
    Downloadable PDF at this link
  • How Critically Can AI Think? A framework for evaluating the quality of thinking of generative artificial intelligence
    Journal article that presents a framework that explores the capabilities of the LLM ChatGPT4 application in relation to educational assignments. Published on arXiv.

Compliance with UConn and AI Usage

According to the UConn Office of Compliance:

UConn has two AI services available to employees – Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft 365 Copilot Chat. These two services are employees' safest data privacy options when using an online AI tool.  Both are fully secure under UConn's agreement with Microsoft, which means they are safe to use with UConn's data. As long as you are signed in with your UConn credentials, your prompts, the information retrieved, and the responses generated are not used to train the underlying AI models.

Alternative AI tools like ChatGPT should not be used in your work at UConn. Any protected or confidential information shared with these AI tools would be used to train the underlying AI models and publicly available. The public disclosure of UConn-protected or confidential information would be in violation of UConn policy. 

 

Which UConn Policies Apply to AI Use?

Data Classification Policy

If housed in the cloud, protected and confidential data is required to be stored only on information systems managed or contracted by the University. Sharing information with other online systems (e.g., opensource cloud solutions, free software-as-a-service offerings, etc.) is not permitted.

 

FERPA Policy

 

University officials may not disclose FERPA-protected student information through any means including AI tools. We may only share student information with a contracted vendor when the vendor is performing a service or function on behalf of the University. 
  • UConn Data Classification Policy
  • UConn FERPA Policy
  • ChatGPT Licenses for UConn Faculty and Staff
    now available via UConn IT. See link above for more info

AI Tools for Summarizing/Analyzing Research Paper Key Points

  • AnswerThis
  • ChatDOC
    Summarize a PDF
  • Chat PDF
    Summarize paper key points, ask questions about a paper's content
  • Consensus: AI search engine for research
  • Coral AI
  • Elicit
  • Explain Paper AI
  • Iris AI
  • OpenRead AI
  • Open Scholar Allen (Semantic Scholar)
    a joint project between Semantic Scholar and the University of Washington, we train and release a fully open, retrieval-augmented language model that can synthesize 8M+ open access research papers to answer scientific questions.
  • Paper Digest
  • Paperbrain AI
  • Petal AI
  • Resoomer
  • Scholarcy
  • Scispace
  • SciSummary
  • Trinka AI from Enago
    grammar and language correction, editing, also checks LaTeX
  • Undermind AI

AI Tool for Analyzing Scientific Research Papers for Errors

  • yesornoerror
    An autonomous DeSci AI agent powered by OpenAI's o1 model, analyzing scientific papers for mathematical errors and discrepancies. Research Hub, the preprint server is a partner of "yesornoerror"
  • Research Hub
    Preprint server that collaborates with "yesornoerror"

AI Tools for Asking Questions and More!

  • Chat GPT
    the most famous and well known generative AI tool; not specifically intended for academic research. Developed by Open AI.
  • Claude AI
    Developed by Anthropic AI
  • Copilot from Microsoft
  • DeepSeek
  • Gemini AI from Google
    Formerly known as Bard
  • Paperpal AI
    AI tool for academic writing and editing
  • Perplexity AI
  • scite_ai

AI Tool (Plug-In) for Math and Science calculations

  • MATLAB Co-pilot
    From MathWorks
  • Wolfram Alpha AI
    Can be added to Chat-GPT

Add a Wolfram topic as a plug-in to your Chat-GPT.  Here is a screen capture that shows the list of  plug-ins available by topic:

  • DeepAI Video Generator
  • Stable video from stability.ai

AI Benchmarking

What is A.I. benchmarking? Artificial intelligence benchmarking involves rating LLMs for errors and hallucinations, and comparing the rate of error to other LLMs.

  • Chatbot Arena (formerly LMSYS)
    Free AI Chat to Compare & Test Best AI Chatbots
  • Epoch AI Data Benchmarking Dashboard
  • Vectara AI Hallucination Leaderboard
    compare hallucination rates of AI chatbots and versions

  • Citation Gecko
  • Connected Papers
  • Inciteful
  • Keenious
  • Litmaps
  • Research Rabbit
  • R Discovery
    An AI app for paper discovery
  • Semantic Scholar AI

AI Tool for Generating Outlines, Structuring Writing, or Notetaking

Learn more about NotebookLM by listening to the podcast linked below!

  • Deep L Write
    check spelling and grammar
  • Hemingway AI
  • Jenni AI
  • LanguageTool
    correct grammar, spelling, and more
  • Moxie AI
    AI tool for academic research and writing assistance
  • NotebookLM from Google
    Summarizes material, can create study guides, also has audio podcast feature
  • Library Journal Podcast Episode on NotebookLM
  • Paperpal AI
    AI tool for academic writing and editing
  • Quillbot
    Checks grammar, for plagiarism, etc
  • Writefull

AI Tools for Systematic Reviews

  • abstrackr
    Link to Brown Univeristy tools abstrackr, SRDR, and OpenMeta [Analyst]. Abstrackr helps you upload and organize the results of a literature search for a systematic review. It also makes it possible for your team to screen, organize, and manipulate all of your abstracts in one place.
  • ASR Review
  • Covidence
  • DistillerSR
  • MAXQDA
    Qualitative data analysis with AI integration
  • Rayyan
  • Next Net
    for biomedical research

AI Tools for Computer Programming Code Review

  • Devin AI
    Created by Cognition Labs
  • Github Co-pilot
    Available by subscription
  • Google Colab
    Test GPT generated code in Python, R; implemented with Jupyter Notebooks

AI Tools for Computational Data Analysis or Data Visualizations

  • Databricks
    Has acquired Einblick
  • Julius AI
  • Powerdrill AI

Other AI Chat Tools:

  • Mistral AI
    French AI and data company, which offers Mistral AI chat

Tools for Text to Speech Conversion

  • ElevenLabs
  • Speechify
  • Natural Reader App
    Text to speech app for PDFs and more
  • Scispace
    Podcast is a feature in Scispace that allows you to listen to an academic journal article in the format of a podcast. It is good for exploring an idea or if an article is relevant.

AI Standards information

AI standards are an emerging topic, which is changing rapidly all the time.

  • AI Standards Hub
    From the UK government; affiliated with Alan Turing Institute
  • ISO (International Organization for Standardization) AI info page
  • ISO AI Management Standard
    Available for purchase only

AI Tools for Image Generation

New AI tools and apps for image generation are always emerging.  These are not necessarily for research purposes, but good to know about for information literacy purposes.  Here are some well known tools:

  • Midjourney
  • Stable Diffusion from Stability AI
  • DALL-E 3 from Open AI

Are you not sure how to tell if an image is real or AI?  Try the test at the link below:

  • Which Face is Real?
    From professors at U of Washington

Not sure where an image is from? Try reverse image searching:

  • Tin Eye Reverse Image Search

Books on AI and University Academics

  • UConn Library Subcollection on AI Literacy and Higher Education Instruction
    books about teaching with AI at the university and secondary level
  • Academic Integrity in the Age of Artificial Intelligence by Saadia Mahmud (Editor)
    ISBN: 9798369302422
    Publication Date: 2024-03-15
    This book dissects the multifaceted impact of AI on the academic landscape The book examines the delicate balance between productivity and ethics while weaving a comprehensive tapestry of insights from various stakeholders.
  • Enhancing Higher Education and Research with OpenAI Models by Şirvan Şen Demir (Editor); Mahmut Demir (Editor)
    ISBN: 9798369316689
    Publication Date: 2024-06-05
    This book explores the intersection of artificial intelligence and higher education, focusing on the social sciences.

Want to learn more about AI tools and academic research?

The university library research guides, webpages, and Open Access books listed below may be useful to you:

  • Carnegie Mellon University Libraries AI Research Guide

  • GenAI Quickstart: Foundations for Faculty
    10 modules from McGill University Library, which address different topics related to generative AI
  • Teaching with AI Images
    From MIT Sloan School of Management
  • Ethics of AI MOOC from U Helsinki
  • AI For Everyone from deeplearning.ai
  • Digital Skills: Artificial Intelligence
    Open Access Book from Charles Sturt University in Australia. Published in 2024
  • Teaching and Generative AI: Pedagogical Possibilities and Productive Tensions
    OA Book from Beth Buyserie, Ph.D., & Travis N. Thurston, Ph.D. of Utah State University

    OA book from IFLA: Balnaves, E., Bultrini, L., Cox, A. & Uzwyshyn, R. (2025). New Horizons in Artificial Intelligence in Libraries. Berlin, Boston: De Gruyter Saur. https://doi.org/10.1515/9783111336435
